moves.1. e4 e5: Most of my chess playing was done in my younger years. I started playing with my dad at a very young age and played my first rated tournament when I was about 12. I peaked my senior year in high school, and then started to lose interest until when I was in my early twenties I hardly played at all. A few years ago I started playing again, and found that my temperament has changed quite a bit. I'm not sure I ever answered 1. e4 with e5 in my whole tournament career!
moves.2. Nf3 Nf6: And I'm quite sure I never played this. It has become quite a staple for me recently, though.
moves.3. Nc3: Surprisingly, I get this response quite often. It is the most passive of white's common responses, and nothing to be afraid of in my opinion.
moves.3... Bb4: Of course, black can continue with ... Nc6 which leads to a four knight's, but this response is more aggressive as well as more keeping with the spirit of the Petroff's.
moves.4. d3: Very passive, although surprisingly I also see this quite often as well. Better alternatives are Nxe5 or Bc4
moves.4... d5 5. exd5 Nxd5 6. Bd2 Nxc3 7. bxc3: Black is already at least equal.
moves.8. Rb1 Nc6 9. Be2 O-O 10. O-O b6 11. Re1: Bb7 was probably better, but I couldn't resist the opportunity to hit white's a pawn.
moves.13. h3: As opposed to black's last pawn push, this one simply wastes time and is weakening.
moves.13... f5 14. Nh2: It is already difficult to suggest moves for white. This ugly move may actually be white's best bet.
moves.14... Qf6 15. c4: A terrible move. Of course, an immediate Bf3 would have been much better.
moves.17... e4: Mixing it up right away. I suppose I could have played an immediate g5 but I was still worried about Bc3
moves.18. Bd1: This doesn't work out very well. On 18. dxe4 fxe4 19. Rxe4 I had planned ... Bxh3, but I think even this is better for white than what actually happened
moves.18... g5 19. Bh5: Forcing me to play what I intended to play anyway.
moves.19... Ng6 20. Bxg6: White didn't have to play this immediately.
moves.20... Qxg6 21. f4: White is desperate for some freedom, but this just opens things up for black
moves.21... gxf4 22. Bxf4 Kh7 23. Kh1: The final blunder. Re2 would have held for a while.
moves.23... Rfg8 24. Re2 exd3 25. cxd3 Bd5: Exclam! White missed this move when he played Kh1
moves.26. cxd5 Rxe2 27. g3 Bxf4 28. Qxf4 Qxg3: And black managed to win the endgame :-)
